results.title: Heritage
results.creator_credit: Department of Agriculture, Canadian Government Motion Picture Bureau and J. Booth-Scott
results.brief_description: Documentary on Western Canada’s prairies and plains where extensive agriculture began in 1890. Wheat was grown in large quantities and became the most important development in the region. Eventually mechanical harvesters were introduced and cities began to grow up overnight. However disaster struck when for eight years there was no rain and by 1932, instead of wheat fields, there was only desert. Overnight dams were built and land reclaimed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Department of Agriculture, Canadian Government Motion Picture Bureau and J. Booth-Scott

results.title: Heritage
results.brief_description: Heritage explores 150 years of Australian history through the nationals myths of the visionary, the pioneer and the nation-builder. Opening with an historical re-enactment, this film evolves into a fictional story of the hard-living, hard-drinking James Morrison and his wife, fiery Irish girl, Biddy OShea. Although they go their separate ways, their paths and those of their children, cross as a nations destiny unfolds. Working with a very small budget , Chauvel was still able to achieve striking set pieces, such as the opening tableau. This film won the first prize in the 1935 Commonwealth Government film competition. For a nation emerging from the Great Depression, it showed pride in the past and faith in the future

results.title: Heritage
results.creator_credit: Australian Expeditionary Films and Charles Chauvel
results.brief_description: Chauvel’s second sound feature was ambitious in scope spanning many decades in Australian history. The films traces the life and loves of James Morrison in colonial times and his descendant Frank Morrison in the 1930s struggling to survive on an outback station with the same determination as his ancestor. Cast, Franklyn Bennett, Norman French, Frank Harvey, Mary Maguire, Harold Meade, Margot Rhys, Joe Valli and Ann Wynn.

results.title: Heredity. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: William L. Claiborne, Acorn Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Microphotography and precise animation are used to visualise chromosomal mechanics and DNA as determinants of human genetic information. Also shows how knowledge of heredity and chromosomal aberrations is being used in genetic counselling, and describes principles of population genetics and how these may lead to genetic similarities and differences.

results.title: Heredity in animals
results.brief_description: The chromosomes in cell nuclei and their relation to the genes for the inherited characters of an animal, the processes of mitosis and meiosis, and the formation of gametes are explained by animated diagrams. Mendel’s first law of segregation and dominance are illustrated. When more than one pair of genes are involved, it is shown how they segregate independently. Cross breeding illustrates the emergence in the second generation of a new type. Results of selective breeding of horses and dogs are also shown.

results.title: Heredity and family environment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology for Living”.
Through a dramatised study of a high-school student, shows that individuals are joint products of heredity and environment. Discusses the roles of heredity and environment, how they mesh in actual living, voluntary and involuntary actions, and the physical effects of emotion.

results.title: Heredity
results.creator_credit: Glen Foster, Country Education Project and David Zweck
results.brief_description: Peter Couchman chairs a discussion between Professor David Danks from the Royal Children’s Hospital and Professor Roger Short from Monash University on issues surrounding genetics. Computerised simulation of matings between domestic animals are used to illustrate the discussion.

results.title: Here, there & back again
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Wayne Hornsby and ACMI
results.brief_description: Wayne Hornsby was in Thailand when he was diagnosed with HIV. He reflects on his journey, nearly dying and his return to Australia, where his work in helping HIV positive people eventually leads him back to Thailand.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Wayne Hornsby and ACMI
